post1.title: Career change: loss, gain, and grounded choices
post1.excerpt: Exploring the emotions that surface when you leave a known role for a new chapter.

paragraphs: Clients considering a career shift often focus on the gain—a new title, flexibility or meaning. Yet any change, even a positive one, carries a sense of loss.
What might be lost? Familiarity, identity, the comfort of expertise, financial stability. Naming these honestly reduces the surprise when grief shows up mid-transition.
article.quote: A coaching space lets us honour what is ending so we can step into what is beginning—without judgement.

sections.heading: Honouring what changes
paragraphs: Before racing ahead, we notice which relationships, routines or markers of success are shifting.
This acknowledgement brings compassion and steadiness when doubt appears later.

sections.heading: Designing the next chapter deliberately
paragraphs: Once losses are seen, we design the habits, conversations and experiments that support the new role.
Coaching helps you test options safely and align choices with your values.

outro: Ask not only ‘What do I want to gain?’ but also ‘What am I willing to release?’ and ‘How will I mark the transition?’.

post2.title: Reading between the lines of the UK job hunt
post2.excerpt: Making sense of the unwritten expectations new arrivals face in the UK job market.

paragraphs: Moving to the UK brings new accents, weather patterns—and job-hunt etiquette. Many newcomers discover hidden rules after sending dozens of applications with no reply.
Coaching sessions often start with frustration. Together we decode what employers expect between the lines.

sections.heading: Reading job descriptions carefully
paragraphs: Words like ‘self-starter’ signal that proactive examples matter more than listing duties.
Showing curiosity about the organisation and linking your story to its mission helps you stand out.

sections.heading: Following up with intention
paragraphs: A short thank-you note after interviews can feel unusual but signals professionalism in the UK context.
Referencing a point from the conversation or sharing a relevant resource shows attentiveness.
list: Summarise what energised you in the discussion.
Connect the role to the organisation’s broader goals.
Invite the interviewer to keep the conversation going if helpful.

article.quote: Cross-cultural transitions are not about abandoning who you are, but expanding how you communicate your strengths.
outro: With practice the job search becomes less about decoding mystery rules and more about sharing your story with clarity.
Coaching creates a space to rehearse, experiment and build confidence.
